name: General
summary: Compilers and Formal Languages (6CCS3CFL)

name: Module Overview
summary:
Handbook: For information on the module syllabus, learning outcomes etc. please see the module page in your department handbook.

Large Group Tutorials: The LGTs will take place on Fridays between 13:00 - 15:00 in:

  • Turing Lecture Theatre (Savoy Place) - Weeks 1, 3, 4, 6, 7
  • Ashworth Centre LT (Lincolns Inn) - Weeks 2, 8, 10
  • Bush House Auditorium (BH N 0) - Week 5
  • St Thomas Nevin LT East Wing (opposite the Houses of Parliament) - Week 9

Assessments:

  • final exam in January (40% -> computer-based, invigilated in some large examination hall)
  • coursework (60%, Part 1 -> optional, Part 2 -> 10%, Part 3 -> 15%, Part 4 -> 15%, Part 5 -> 20%)

name: What the students say...
summary:
"I really enjoyed taking CFL. It was an intense module, sometimes too intense when things weren't working, but I really enjoyed actually learning what goes on behind the scenes of a compiler. I also really enjoyed working with LLVM, which I've never touched before, and studying how it works and how LLVM-IR differs from JVM bytecode (which I've also never worked with before). I always liked looking up different kinds of programming languages and how they worked, so to actually implement one myself? Man! It was a tense experience, and it really required some strenuous thinking, but in retrospect, CFL was incredibly enjoyable, and I've achieved a lot out of it. Definitely one of my favourite modules in this entire course!" -- Zishan Rahman in year 2022/23

"I enjoyed the module - it was genuinely the stand out academic experience of my undergraduate degree, and very much influenced my career interests. In fact I am currently working at ARM, in their Open Source Software group, on AArch64 specific optimisations for the Java/Kotlin compiler that forms part of the Android Runtime." -- Hari Limaye in year 2021/22

"After having studied the CFL module, I have now a much bigger interest towards the world of compilers; in fact, I even have applied to some companies that specifically work with them." -- Alfredo Musumeci in year 2021/22 (he received an offer from ARM to work there after his study)

"I thoroughly enjoyed this module and it helped a lot in my individual project. Christian was a really great lecturer and provided a lot of helpful information and advice." -- Aleksandr Vorontsov in year 2020/21

"I'm extremely happy I decided to take this module: it has been my favourite class while in university so far. I have learned so many things and I feel like my perspective on computer science has definitely become wider. You are extremely knowledgeable and the passion you put in this class was really visible!" -- Catalin Torge in year 2019/20

"This module made me appreciate functional programming more." -- Petru-Armand Bancila in year 2017/18

"The course changed my perspective on understanding how programming languages fundamentally work and I can honestly say it was the best course that I have been to throughout university." -- Andrei Nae-Stroie in year 2016/17

"The Compilers and Formal Languages module is amazing because I learned a lot and it is a really good balance of both theory and practice." -- Konstantin Terziev in year 2016/17

"I am extremely satisfied with this module and especially with the coursework, as it really helped me understand the material better. Also I am delighted with the responsiveness and help offered by the lecturer outside of lectures." -- Ana Mihai in year 2015/16

"I very much enjoyed your module and I feel like I have learned a lot." -- Tommy Lewis in year 2014/15

name: Assessments
summary: This section contains information regarding the assessment criteria, methods, and weighting for this module.

name: Coursework
summary: The coursework needs to be uploaded to Github (see 3-step process below). You can use any programming language you like, but you need to submit the source code with which you solved the questions, otherwise a mark of 0% will be awarded. If you use a different programming language from Scala, then you need to add an explanation for how to run your code.

modules.name: (Step 0) Plagiarism and Collusion Training
modules.description:
You must complete this quiz before you make any coursework submissions.

As all the module marks are from coursework, the penalties for academic misconduct can be severe. Do not take shortcuts by submitting work that you have plagiarised from other sources, or is a result of collusion with another student. Likewise, take care of your own work - do not show your answer to other students, do not store it on pastebin (where search engines can find it), do not put it in a public git repository, and so on.

name: Week 1 (Introduction)
summary:
Lecture 1 introduces the background of compilers and gives you my take on why it is interesting to study them. The overall aim of this module is to let you implement a small compiler, building on the implementation I will show and explain to you. This compiler will be broken up into 5 courseworks, which I will tell you in this lecture how they fit together in the end. In the first lecture we will also learn about regular expressions and (formal) languages.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • know what basic and extended regular expressions are
  • know what languages are and how they relate to regular expressions

modules.name: A paper about program redundancies in Boeing 777s

contents.filename: A paper about program redundancies in Boeing 777s

name: Week 2 (Regular Expressions, Derivatives)
summary:
Lecture 2 is about a regular expression matcher that uses the notion of derivatives. This avoids problems with catastrophic backtracking and can be implemented with ease in a functional programming language. Students need to understand what derivatives of regular expressions are and how they relate to the semantics of regular expressions.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • know about the notions of nullable and derivatives
  • know how to implement the derivative-based matching algorithm

modules.name: coursework 1 (10 mins): Note that this is an UNMARKED cw

contents.filename: Formally Verified Software in the Real World

modules.name: Matcher.thy (Isabelle code for proving the correctness of Brzozowski's matcher)

contents.filename: Matcher.thy (Isabelle code for proving the correctness of Brzozowskis matcher)

name: Week 3 (Automata, Regular Languages)
summary:
Lecture 3 looks at the relation between regular expressions and automata (deterministic and non-deterministic). This is for finding out why common regular expression matchers are sometimes so abysmally slow. The correspondence also establishes the notion of what a regular language is.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • know how regular expressions are translated into NFAs and DFAs, and vice-versa
  • know about the Thompson and subset constructions

modules.name: Regular Expression to NFA and DFA Calculator

contents.filename: Regular Expression to NFA and DFA Calculator

modules.name: An interesting discussion about regex matching in Rust

contents.filename: An interesting discussion about regex matching in Rust

modules.name: A page about regexes in Go

contents.filename: A page about regexes in Go

name: Week 4 (Lexing)
summary:
Lecture 4 extends the derivative-based regular expression matcher from Lecture 2 to do lexing. Students need to understand how the injection function generates values and how tokens can be extracted from values.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • know about the notion of values and the functions injection and simp
  • know how to generate tokens for programming languages by defining regular expressions

name: Week 5 (Grammars, Parsing)
summary:
Lecture 5 is about context-free grammars and parsing algorithms. Issues such as left-recursion and ambiguity will be discussed.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • design context-free grammars and know about left-recursion and ambiguity
  • know about the CYK algorithm and its complexity

modules.name: Survey of Parsing Techniques in Major Languages

contents.filename: Survey of Parsing Techniques in Major Languages

name: Week 6 (Parser Combinators, While-Language)
summary:
Lecture 6 is about parser combinators and interpreters. The grammar for the While language will be discussed.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • know how to implement parser combinators
  • know how to write an interpreter for the While language

modules.name: FastParse: A talk by Li Haoyi about a Combinator Parsing Library in Scala (gives some background on parsing)

contents.filename: FastParse A talk by Li Haoyi about a Combinator Parsing Library in Scala (gives some background on parsing)

name: Week 7 (Compilation, JVM)
summary:
Lecture 7 is about generating JVM code for the While language.

Learning Objectives By the end of this week you should:

  • know how to read JVM code
  • know how to generate JVM code for the While language

modules.name: compile_bfc.sc (BF transpiler to While using fastparse library)

contents.filename: compile_bfc.sc (BF transpiler to While using fastparse library)

name: Week 8 (Compiling Functional Languages)
summary: We continue with compiling the While language and also start with looking at a small functional language.

name: Week 9 (Optimisations)
summary: We compile a small functional language and look how code can be optimised.

contents.filename: The Surprising Subtleties of Zeroing a Register

name: Week 10 (LLVM)
summary: I will explain the LLVM-IR and how to compile the fun language to the LLVM-IR via an intermediate language. The hard part in section is the CPS translation.
